MEDICAL NOTICE.

nj BERNARD BARTON.
Thou hast thy beauties; stormer ones own
ahan those OF thy precursors; yet to thee
Belong the charms of solemn majesty
And naked grandeur. Awful is the tone
OF thy tempesuous nights, when clounds are blown
ny hurrying winds across the troubled sky;
Pensve, when softer breezes family sigh.
Through leaAess boughs, with ivy overgrown,
Thou hast thy decorations. too although
Thou art austere; thy studded mantle, gay
With icy brilliants, which as proudly glow
As erst Golconda's: and Thy pure array
or regal ermine, when the drf'ed snow
Enyelops nature still her features seem
Like pale, but lovely ones seen when we dream
WINTER.
nj BERNARD BARTON.

! .dnecdote et Dr. Frdnktln.-The Doctor was
walking day on Front street, Chestnut street,


IN the city OF Philadelphia, at the dawn Of our Rev
olution, when he was thus accosted by Tar:


"Is your ramc Ben Frankln?" Yes. care you
the man VIZ invented the saw dust pudding =" Yes,
replied the ,c,or. Them said the sailor for
Coos sake at give the receipt to make il to old
F, our gaerchant, as he will feed all his crews
on it,"


| The story the saw dust pudding. alter dictum,
wheat bran ,,1dding arose in this manner. The
Doctor had nducted an independent paper in Phil
adelphia, whica gave offence to a class who wanted
10 rule every body in their own way and the heads
OF this party, some fifteen twenty, informed the
Doctor that they would frown him down, unless he
would submit to the curb. The Doctor proposed
10 explain, and Fixed the time at his own house,
where the gentlemen were invited TO dine. He re-
quesred his lady to employ two pence in the pur
chase Of peck of white bran. and TO make two pud
dings Of it-one for each end Of the table, az he
was to have fifteen twenty friends to dine with him
The company met-the two puddings were served
on table, without any other dishes-the company
sat down, and each friend was served with his slice
OF pudding. The curiosity led them to Try it, they
examined each Others countenances, and at length
we're saated with the pudding. Friends, says tn.
Doctor will you be helped 10 more No, they allre
piled, We have enough OF your pudding. But what
means this Why, replied The Doctor. il means

| and fifteen friends say they have enough Know then
ths, as long Benjamin Franklin satisfy fifteen
friends with two pence, he never will sacrifice he
independence Of his paper Charleston Courier.


.Npw Mineral Springs apparatus of Mr..

ring the cold weather, they intend to commence

the gallon ". Y. Times.
Want Of Panetunlity.-" In many cases, it a.
mounts to robbery. short time since in village
in the neig ghbourhood Of London. a committee of
eight ladies'. who managed the concerns Of an instr
tuition which had been formed for the relief OF the
neighbouring poor, agreed to meet on a certain day
~ t"CVC SioIh PtCeioc'J. oCNcu vi tnci ducuucu
punctusy at the appointed hour the eighth did not
arrive till quarter of an hour after She came in
according to the usual mode, with, I'm very sorry
to be behind in the time appointed, but really the
time slipped away without my being sensible Of it
hope your goodness will excuse it,


One Of the ladies who was Quaker, replied.
Truly friend it doth not appear clear TO me that
we ought TO accept OF thine apology. Hadst thy
self only lost quarter of an hour, would have been
merely thy concern; but in this case, the quarter
must be multiplied by eight. ss we have each lost
quarter; so that there have been two hours OF
useful time sacrificed BY thy want of punctuslity."


Polishing A person in public company accu
sing the Irish nation with being the most unpublished
in the world. was answered mildly by an Irish gen
,leman. "hat it ought to be otherwise tor the Irish
met with hard rubs enough to polish any nation an
earth"

unfathom'd deep, unfruer'd waste
OF never silent waves,
Each by its rushing follower cbas'd,
Through un,llumnd caves.
And DER the rocks whose tnrrets rude,
Fen, since the birth of time,
Hath heard amid thy solitude,


The bows ceaseless chime.
Thro' what recesses, depths unknown,
Dost thou thy waves impel,
Where never yet sunbeam shone,
Or CLEAN of moonlight fell
For never yet did mortal eyes


Thy gloom-w rapt deeps behold,
And nought of thy dread mysteries,
The tongue Of man hath told.
What though proud man presume TO hold
His course upon thy tide,
Ger thy dark billovs uncontrol'd


His fragile bark 10 guide
Yet who, upon thy mountain waves,
Can feel himself secure,
While sweeping DER thy yawning caves,
Deep, awful and obscure
But thou art mild and tranquil now
Thy wrathful spirits sleep.
And gentle blows, calm ard slow


Across thy boom sweep.
Yet where the dim horizons bound


Rests on thy sparkling bed,
The tempest.cloud, in gloom p, ofound.
Prepares its wrath to she'd.
Thus, mild and calm in youths bright hour.
The tide Of life appears,
When fancy paints, with magic power,


The bliss Of coming years;
But clouds will rise, and darkness bring
O'er life's deceitful way,
And cruel disappointment fling


Its blight on hopes dim ray. w.
OCEAN.

Who that has ever been the stage OF public
life, but will admit the justice of the following oh
servalions:


Differences 1T is markable that men. when
they differ in any hing considerable, which they
think consider able, will be apt to differ in almost
every thing else. Their differences beget contra
dic,ion. Contradiction begets beat. Heat quickly
rises into resentment, rage, and l.~ill. Thus,
they differ in affections as they differ in judgment
anh the conleu,ion which began tn pride, ends in
ans.s Cato's Letters.

full articles.headline:
WINTER.

nj BERNARD BARTON.
full articles.article:
nj BERNARD BARTON.
Thou hast thy beauties; stormer ones own
ahan those OF thy precursors; yet to thee
Belong the charms of solemn majesty
And naked grandeur. Awful is the tone
OF thy tempesuous nights, when clounds are blown
ny hurrying winds across the troubled sky;
Pensve, when softer breezes family sigh.
Through leaAess boughs, with ivy overgrown,
Thou hast thy decorations. too although
Thou art austere; thy studded mantle, gay
With icy brilliants, which as proudly glow
As erst Golconda's: and Thy pure array
or regal ermine, when the drf'ed snow
Enyelops nature still her features seem
Like pale, but lovely ones seen when we dream

| On the 10Th of December, the united forces oil
the Disric,s OF Nscogdoches and the Aysh Bayou

d. Mt of Mexico and hoisted flag with the words
: Liberty end Independence" on It, II is stated
this new tepuogc is called The Republic of Fre-
do Ia" and that their flag consists Of stripe OF red
and white, being emilia attic OF union between the
red ard white men, as it is stated that the change

hat the FredoDisns were shoUi TO proceed against

gress. is TO assemble at Nacogdocbes on the first
Monday in February, TO form Constitution and
appoint Executive Ofcers. The following gentle.
men have been eitced Col. H. Edwards, 3. Ed
wards. ESQ Fl Iayo, Esq. Col. Legion, MIR.

F'om Tp.ros We have information OF disposition
on the part OF the Americans who have emigrsted
thither, 10 declare themselves independent ci Mex.
ico and that they have ever gone far ta elect
persons TO compose Congress or Convention to
form Constitution.


We havcs feeling for all People willing to be free
and struggling under oppression but az we under
stand the matter. We have little sympathy with the
Revolutionists Of Texas.


Texas is part of the Republic Of Mexico, and
the people who inhahit il are probably more free
from burthcns and exactops than they would be
under government Of their own. The emigrants
thither from this country have. entering the lin
its. enjoyed the hospitality of the Government.
They are represented in the Government--they en-.
ny equal rights with other citizens OF the Republic.
II the, do not. have heard that they do not
I These benefits they are about to reque by turning
heir arms against their benefactots. They have
mistaken spirit Of adventure and encroachment ior
10 vearning sfer Independence. and have projected
revolution 10 reality possessing all the features oil
rebellion and invasion, wi hout preext OF such mo-
ives an ia low inc one bNu JuStUy inc OtnET.


The object Of these Independents is, we ptesume,
TO ofer the Territory thus declared independents TO
he United States. But The Government OF The u
rned States would (alwsys speaking our own opin.
ior ony) be faithless 10 the most solemn engage
nenls. u the most friendly professions which it
has made and repeated to the Government OF Mex
leo were IL to accept such present.


We not long ago, by solemn Tsea,y, left Texas
in possession OF Spain. as part Of Mexico. Mexco
hoo ipIe spdenf Repuhiir Shall
we AXE from young Republic (for it would be ia
kinE) hat we would not lake from an old and des
po,ic Monarchy? Justice, generosity, and regard
tor national cha acter forbid such treachery to
the principle OF good faith by which this country
has been guided in its relations with foreign
powers.


But, il no consideration Of principle intervened
to induce the Government Of the United States to
withhold its countcnaDce from these g. Independ
ents. sound poiicy forbids it. 1t is not the policy
OF this country to encourage revolution here, rev
olution there and revolution every where. IL 10
rather OF consequence TO US to promote the stability
ot Governments in all tries, where Governments
are founded on the free Representative principle.
Such is the in Mexico. 1t is interest also
TO preserve the relations OF peace and smi'y with
Mexico. which would be utterly dsregarded BY the
afording aid or countenance 10 her citizens in
arms against her. ard only in the mselves,
but actually ensting the savage tribes IN their pro
ects, 10 carry fire and sword into the peaceabe do
mains OF The Nation of which they have voluntarily
become citizens Nat Intel

! .dnecdote et Dr. Frdnktln.-The Doctor was
walking day on Front street, Chestnut street,


IN the city OF Philadelphia, at the dawn Of our Rev
olution, when he was thus accosted by Tar:


"Is your ramc Ben Frankln?" Yes. care you
the man VIZ invented the saw dust pudding =" Yes,
replied the ,c,or. Them said the sailor for
Coos sake at give the receipt to make il to old
F, our gaerchant, as he will feed all his crews
on it,"


| The story the saw dust pudding. alter dictum,
wheat bran ,,1dding arose in this manner. The
Doctor had nducted an independent paper in Phil
adelphia, whica gave offence to a class who wanted
10 rule every body in their own way and the heads
OF this party, some fifteen twenty, informed the
Doctor that they would frown him down, unless he
would submit to the curb. The Doctor proposed
10 explain, and Fixed the time at his own house,
where the gentlemen were invited TO dine. He re-
quesred his lady to employ two pence in the pur
chase Of peck of white bran. and TO make two pud
dings Of it-one for each end Of the table, az he
was to have fifteen twenty friends to dine with him
The company met-the two puddings were served
on table, without any other dishes-the company
sat down, and each friend was served with his slice
OF pudding. The curiosity led them to Try it, they
examined each Others countenances, and at length
we're saated with the pudding. Friends, says tn.
Doctor will you be helped 10 more No, they allre
piled, We have enough OF your pudding. But what
means this Why, replied The Doctor. il means
10 yUu tHdt tHcdc TWO puuuHlRb COST TWO pence
| and fifteen friends say they have enough Know then
ths, as long Benjamin Franklin satisfy fifteen
friends with two pence, he never will sacrifice he
independence Of his paper Charleston Courier.


.Npw Mineral Springs apparatus of Mr..
Disbrow, which has been usrfully employed here
and else where in boring for fresh and pure water
has been recently used by some gentlemen OF Ball
ston Spa, in several parts OF that town. The Balls
ton Gazette inoi ms, that, alter ating he
earth to the depth Of 30 feet, they found Mineral
Water, which was surcharged with carbonic acid
gas, and contained all The mineral properties Of
other fountains, and rose freely from a to feet
above the surface. discharglne at the OF about
gallon per minute They have penetrated the
earth to the depth o! l7o feet, and in
magnetism calcarous slate rock and although they
have discontinued operations for the present, du
ring the cold weather, they intend to commence
again the opening Of the spring. There is every
prospect of their finding Saline water, as at the
depth of 80 feet, it contained 240 grains Of salt
the gallon ". Y. Times.
Want Of Panetunlity.-" In many cases, it a.
mounts to robbery. short time since in village
in the neig ghbourhood Of London. a committee of
eight ladies'. who managed the concerns Of an instr
tuition which had been formed for the relief OF the
neighbouring poor, agreed to meet on a certain day
~ t"CVC SioIh PtCeioc'J. oCNcu vi tnci ducuucu
punctusy at the appointed hour the eighth did not
arrive till quarter of an hour after She came in
according to the usual mode, with, I'm very sorry
to be behind in the time appointed, but really the
time slipped away without my being sensible Of it
hope your goodness will excuse it,


One Of the ladies who was Quaker, replied.
Truly friend it doth not appear clear TO me that
we ought TO accept OF thine apology. Hadst thy
self only lost quarter of an hour, would have been
merely thy concern; but in this case, the quarter
must be multiplied by eight. ss we have each lost
quarter; so that there have been two hours OF
useful time sacrificed BY thy want of punctuslity."


Polishing A person in public company accu
sing the Irish nation with being the most unpublished
in the world. was answered mildly by an Irish gen
,leman. "hat it ought to be otherwise tor the Irish
met with hard rubs enough to polish any nation an

full articles.headline: OCEAN.
full articles.article:
unfathom'd deep, unfruer'd waste
OF never silent waves,
Each by its rushing follower cbas'd,
Through un,llumnd caves.
And DER the rocks whose tnrrets rude,
Fen, since the birth of time,
Hath heard amid thy solitude,


The bows ceaseless chime.
Thro' what recesses, depths unknown,
Dost thou thy waves impel,
Where never yet sunbeam shone,
Or CLEAN of moonlight fell
For never yet did mortal eyes


Thy gloom-w rapt deeps behold,
And nought of thy dread mysteries,
The tongue Of man hath told.
What though proud man presume TO hold
His course upon thy tide,
Ger thy dark billovs uncontrol'd


His fragile bark 10 guide
Yet who, upon thy mountain waves,
Can feel himself secure,
While sweeping DER thy yawning caves,
Deep, awful and obscure
But thou art mild and tranquil now
Thy wrathful spirits sleep.
And gentle blows, calm ard slow


Across thy boom sweep.
Yet where the dim horizons bound


Rests on thy sparkling bed,
The tempest.cloud, in gloom p, ofound.
Prepares its wrath to she'd.
Thus, mild and calm in youths bright hour.
The tide Of life appears,
When fancy paints, with magic power,


The bliss Of coming years;
But clouds will rise, and darkness bring
O'er life's deceitful way,
And cruel disappointment fling


Its blight on hopes dim ray. w.

Who that has ever been the stage OF public
life, but will admit the justice of the following oh
servalions:


Differences 1T is markable that men. when
they differ in any hing considerable, which they
think consider able, will be apt to differ in almost
every thing else. Their differences beget contra
dic,ion. Contradiction begets beat. Heat quickly
rises into resentment, rage, and l.~ill. Thus,
they differ in affections as they differ in judgment
anh the conleu,ion which began tn pride, ends in
ans.s Cato's Letters.
